elements.content: We isolated a coordination polymer with the formula [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf, with three unique EuIII coordination sites in the asymmetric unit, with the EuIII ions bridged by 3,5-dichlorobenzoato (3,5-dcba) ligands. The coordination polymer crystallized in the triclinic space group P1̅ with unit cell dimensions a = 12.4899(15), b = 16.326(2), and c = 25.059(3) Å, α = 84.271(3)°, β = 84.832(3)°, and γ = 68.585(3)° and V = 4725.2(10) Å3. The characteristic 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0–4) EuIII transitions were observed upon ligand-centered excitation. Emission lifetimes of 0.825 ± 0.085 and 1.586 ± 0.057 ms were observed and were attributed to the sites with coordination of water or dimethylformamide (dmf) molecules to each ion, respectively. Through a combination of spectroscopy and calculations, we determined the photophysical properties of each unique EuIII site. Energy-transfer rates ligand → EuIII were determined for each unique site using the overlapped polyhedra method. The rates depend on the coordinated water molecules and the different donor–acceptor distances. The two sites without coordinated water molecules and shortest donor–acceptor distance display the fastest energy-transfer rate ligand → EuIII, whereas the site with coordinated water molecules and longest donor–acceptor distance displays the slowest energy-transfer rate. Donor–acceptor distances were estimated computationally and were confirmed by calculating the frontier orbitals in the asymmetric units of the polymer using density functional theory.

The characteristic 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 0-4) EuIII transitions were observed upon ligand-centered excitation. Emission lifetimes of 0.825 ± 0.085 and 1.586 ± 0.057 ms were observed and were attributed to the sites with coordination of water or dimethylformamide (dmf) molecules to each ion, respectively. Through a combination of spectroscopy and calculations, we determined the photophysical properties of each unique EuIII site. Energy-transfer rates ligand → EuIII were determined for each unique site using the overlapped polyhedra method. The two sites without coordinated water molecules and shortest donor-acceptor distance display the fastest energy-transfer rate ligand → EuIII, whereas the site with coordinated water molecules and longest donor-acceptor distance displays the slowest energy-transfer rate. Donor-acceptor distances were estimated computationally and were confirmed by calculating the frontier orbitals in the asymmetric units of the polymer using density functional theory.

elements.content: The coordination polymer [Eu­(3,5-dcba)3(H2O)­(dmf)3]·dmf with three unique EuIII coordination sites in the asymmetric unit was isolated and the photophysical properties of each unique EuIII site were determined using a combination of spectroscopy and calculations. Energy-transfer rates ligand → EuIII and radiative rates were determined for each unique site using the overlapped polyhedra method; donor−acceptor distances were estimated using LUMPAC and confirmed by calculating the frontier orbitals in the asymmetric units of the polymer using density functional theory calculations.

elements.content: Lanthanide­(III) (LnIII) luminescent compounds are useful for lighting, displays, bioimaging, sensing, and diagnostics. The characteristic 4f–4f narrow bands lead to high emission color purity, and the long emission lifetimes enable the use of time-gated detection for improved signal-to-noise ratio. Because of the low molar absorptivity of direct 4f–4f excitation, organic ligands are usually used as sensitizers in a process called the antenna effect. In this process, energy is absorbed by the ligand, transferred to the LnIII that then emits through the 4f–4f transitions. Tailoring the chemical properties and electronic structure of the sensitizers results in LnIII complexes with specific properties such as high emission quantum yields, absorption in the visible, affinity for specific cells, water solubility, and sensing of ions or gases, among others.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Lanthanide(III) (LnIII) luminescent compounds are useful for lighting, displays, bioimaging, sensing, and diagnostics. The characteristic 4f-4f narrow bands lead to high emission color purity, and the long emission lifetimes enable the use of time-gated detection for improved signal-to-noise ratio. Because of the low molar absorptivity of direct 4f-4f excitation, organic ligands are usually used as sensitizers in a process called the antenna effect. In this process, energy is absorbed by the ligand, transferred to the LnIII that then emits through the 4f-4f transitions. Tailoring the chemical properties and electronic structure of the sensitizers results in LnIII complexes with specific properties such as high emission quantum yields, absorption in the visible, affinity for specific cells, water solubility, and sensing of ions or gases, among others.

elements.content: Recently, Borbas and Andres showed a simple and elegant synthetic method to quickly screen the photophysics and sensitization ability of chromophores. Nonetheless, syntheses are often cumbersome, and thus routine screening of large numbers of sensitizers is time consuming. On the other hand, theoretical methods can aid in designing and evaluating the best system for a given application. The development of user friendly software packages such as LUMPAC has increased the popularity of theoretical methods among traditionally experimental research groups to explain experimental observations and predict structural and optical properties. The ideal theoretical method should precisely estimate bond lengths and symmetry around the LnIII, as the latter correlates with the photophysical properties. The Judd–Ofelt (JO) intensity parameters, which describe the symmetry around the LnIII, can be determined experimentally and also calculated and are therefore a good benchmark for the quality of the modeling.

The development of user friendly software packages such as LUMPAC has increased the popularity of theoretical methods among traditionally experimental research groups to explain experimental observations and predict structural and optical properties. The ideal theoretical method should precisely estimate bond lengths and symmetry around the LnIII, as the latter correlates with the photophysical properties. The Judd-Ofelt (JO) intensity parameters, which describe the symmetry around the LnIII, can be determined experimentally and also calculated and are therefore a good benchmark for the quality of the modeling.

elements.content: The JO parameters are calculated by adjusting the charge factor (g) and polarizability (α) of each ligand-bound europium to reproduce the experimental ones. However, when the system has two or more unique EuIII coordination sites, this procedure leads to inconsistent results because the experimental JO intensity parameters cannot be determined for each unique metal ion and its coordination polyhedron and this fact precludes the individual theoretical adjustment. Thus, the known theoretical studies involve monometallic complexes. While Wen et al. successfully used complete-active-space self-consistent field energies and wave functions to extract the crystal-field parameters of CeIII in solids and molecules, the analysis of larger systems requires long computation times and therefore examples of systems containing more than one unique LnIII, such as some dimers or coordination polymers, remain scarce.

elements.content: To overcome this limitation, Freire and co-workers proposed three strategies to calculate the luminescence properties in a system containing two or more different EuIII coordination sites, namely, the centroid method, the individual polyhedron method (IPM), and the overlapped polyhedra method (OPM). In the centroid method, the EuIII centers are replaced by a centroid, a dummy atom located at the midpoint between the ions. In this case, all the ligand atoms are coordinated to the centroid, and the fitting of the JO intensity parameters is performed for the centroid. In the IPM, the adjustment of the JO intensity parameters is performed for each polyhedron individually. If two centers share common ligand atoms, average g and α values are considered to obtain the information regarding each center. Finally, in the OPM, the polyhedra are initially superimposed, and the spherical coordinates of all ligand atoms associated with a single EuIII center are obtained. The values of g and α for each ligand atom are adjusted to fit the experimental JO intensity parameters and then the values of g and α obtained are applied to each center individually.

In the centroid method, the EuIII centers are replaced by a centroid, a dummy atom located at the midpoint between the ions. In this case, all the ligand atoms are coordinated to the centroid, and the fitting of the JO intensity parameters is performed for the centroid. In the IPM, the adjustment of the JO intensity parameters is performed for each polyhedron individually. If two centers share common ligand atoms, average g and α values are considered to obtain the information regarding each center. Finally, in the OPM, the polyhedra are initially superimposed, and the spherical coordinates of all ligand atoms associated with a single EuIII center are obtained. The values of g and α for each ligand atom are adjusted to fit the experimental JO intensity parameters and then the values of g and α obtained are applied to each center individually.

elements.content: The approaches reported by Freire and co-workers have been used to calculate spectroscopic parameters for compounds containing no more than two different EuIII coordination sites. Here, we extend this theoretical approach to describe the optical properties of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf, which has three unique EuIII coordination sites in the asymmetric unit. This coordination polymer was isolated by reacting 3,5-dcba (3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid) with EuCl3. We characterized this new compound by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and emission spectroscopy and used theory to describe the optical properties for each unique EuIII coordination site.

We characterized this new compound by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and emission spectroscopy and used theory to describe the optical properties for each unique EuIII coordination site.

elements.content: The complex [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf was obtained by reacting 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid in NaOH with europium chloride, and X-ray quality single crystals were isolated from diffusion of water into a DMF solution. This complex crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, as a coordination polymer with unit cell dimensions a = 12.4899(15), b = 16.326(2), and c = 25.059(3) Å, α = 84.271(3), β = 84.832(3), and γ = 68.585(3)° and V = 4725.2(10) Å3. Although one or two different sites for LnIII ions are often encountered for complexes containing benzoic acid and its derivatives, here there are three unique EuIII coordination sites, as shown in , with the three unique EuIII ions bridged by κ2-O-3,5-dichlorobenzoato anions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The complex [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)(dmf)3]⋅2dmf was obtained by reacting 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid in NaOH with europium chloride, and X-ray quality single crystals were isolated from diffusion of water into a DMF solution. This complex crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, as a coordination polymer with unit cell dimensions a = 12.4899(15), b = 16.326(2), and c = 25.059(3) Å, α = 84.271(3), β = 84.832(3), and γ = 68.585(3)° and V = 4725.2(10) Å3. Although one or two different sites for LnIII ions are often encountered for complexes containing benzoic acid and its derivatives, here there are three unique EuIII coordination sites, as shown in , with the three unique EuIII ions bridged by κ2-O-3,5-dichlorobenzoato anions.

elements.content: Eu1 is in a square antiprismatic coordination environment, surrounded by eight oxygen atoms, as shown in a, one of which is the oxygen atom of a coordinated dimethylformamide (dmf) molecule, four correspond to bridging carboxylato oxygen atoms to ion Eu2, two are oxygen atoms of a chelating benzoato, and the final oxygen atom corresponds to a bridging carboxylato to Eu3. Eu2 is in a distorted square antiprismatic coordination environment (b), with six oxygen atoms corresponding to bridging carboxylato moieties and two from bound dmf molecules. Eu3 displays a coordination number of 7, in a monocapped trigonal prism environment (c), in which the base and top of the prism are oxygen atoms of bridging carboxylato moieties and the capping atom corresponds to a coordinated water molecule.

elements.content: The Eu–O bond distances are in the range 2.27–2.60 Å, within the expected values for complexes with carboxylato ligands. The shortest bond distance corresponds to a bridging carboxylato oxygen atom in the top face of the trigonal prism from Eu3, while the longest is from Eu1 to an oxygen atom of the bidentate carboxylato. The distance to the oxygen atom from the water molecule at 2.416 Å is also within the expected, as are the distances of 2.425, 2.464, and 2.486 Å to the oxygen atoms of the bound dmf molecules.

elements.content: The one-dimensional coordination polymer extends along the c axis, as shown in . The EuIII ions are bridged by the dichlorobenzoato ligands, and one of these ligands, bound to Eu1, is in close contact to its symmetry-related counterpart, with a close Cl−π interaction () of 3.46 Å. The planes spanned by these two ligands are at a distance of 3.3 Å and a centroid-to-centroid distance of 4.4 Å, which indicates the presence of weak π–π stacking interactions between adjacent coordination polymer strands ().

elements.content: The excitation spectrum of the complex is composed of an intense broad ligand-based band and weaker narrow f–f bands, which indicate that, while direct EuIII excitation occurs, the main sensitization pathway is through the ligand.

elements.content: The emission spectrum of the EuIII complex displays the characteristic EuIII transitions 5D0 → 7F J , (J = 0–4). The intensity and splitting pattern of these transitions provide information about the symmetry around the EuIII ion and the degree of covalency of the Eu–ligand bonds. Here, the narrow band attributed to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is more intense than the 5D0 → 7F1 one, indicating that the forced electric dipole and the dynamic coupling mechanisms dominate over the magnetic dipole one because all three EuIII ions are located in low symmetry sites without an inversion center.

Here, the narrow band attributed to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is more intense than the 5D0 → 7F1 one, indicating that the forced electric dipole and the dynamic coupling mechanisms dominate over the magnetic dipole one because all three EuIII ions are located in low symmetry sites without an inversion center.

elements.content:
To get a better insight into the symmetry around the EuIII ions in [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf, the JO intensity parameters were determined from the spectroscopic data ().

Ω2 and Ω4 are strongly correlated with the symmetry around the EuIII ion. Ω2 is larger than Ω4, which indicates that the EuIII is in a low symmetry site. The environments around the EuIII ions in the complex are, on average, more symmetric when compared with [Eu­(4-iba)3(H2O)­(dmf)]2 (4-iba = 4-iodobenzoato), for which values of Ω2 and Ω4 of 13.4 and 5.5, respectively, were reported, and less symmetric when compared with [Eu­(ppa)3] (ppa = phenylphosphinato), for which values of Ω2 and Ω4 of 3.4 and 0.8, respectively, were reported.

The percent contribution of each site is shown in parenthesis.

The emission decay curve of the 5D0 (EuIII) emitting level of the [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf could be fitted using a double exponential decay function (Figure S2), and the corresponding lifetimes (τ) are summarized in . While there are three unique EuIII sites in the asymmetric unit, two share the same coordination geometry, each with one bound water molecule ( and ), which translates into the double exponential decay function and two lifetimes. As there is a strong correlation between the lifetime and the nonradiative processes such as O–H and N–H oscillators, we assigned the longest lifetime to the sites with one and two coordinated dmf molecules (Eu1 and Eu2, respectively) and the shortest one to the site with one coordinated water molecule (Eu3). This assignment was confirmed by comparing the observed (τ) and radiative (τrad) lifetimes of the compound. When using , the lifetimes confirm that, for this complex, one site has ∼0.6, close to 1, and the other two sites zero water molecules coordinated to the metal ion (). The intrinsic quantum yield () was determined using . The intrinsic quantum yield is strongly correlated with the nonradiative processes, such as vibronic coupling with O–H oscillators or energy back transfer from EuIII to ligand levels. The value of 51% obtained for this complex, higher than values reported for similar complexes, again confirms the presence of coordinated solvent dmf molecules and only one water molecule.

elements.content: To theoretically study the photophysical properties and unravel the individual contributions of each EuIII ion to the overall spectroscopic properties of the coordination polymer, we first calculated the JO intensity parameters, (Ωλ)method (λ = 2, 4, and 6 and method = IPM or OPM). As mentioned above, three different approaches can be used to estimate these parameters for polynuclear compounds with two or more unique centers. The centroid method was not applied here due to the short atomic distances between the atoms coordinated to polyhedron 2 and the centroid of three centers. As the distance used to calculate the parameter Ω6 is raised to the power of seven, very large and nonapplicable values of Ω6 were obtained. The results obtained with the IPM and the OPM are discussed below.

elements.content: The data obtained with the IPM are summarized in . Determination of the JO intensity parameters and of the photophysical properties using this method was unsuccessful. For polyhedra 1 and 2, the calculated (Ω4)IPM values are higher than the (Ω2)IPM values. This result is expected when EuIII is located in high symmetry sites (O h , T d , or D n groups, e.g.), which is not the case, as seen by crystallography (). Analysis of the theoretical photophysical properties of each site indicates that polyhedron 3 contributes the most to A rad. That is physically impossible, as the water molecule coordinated to Eu3 decreases the radiative emission rates due to O–H vibrational coupling.

Applying the OPM was complicated by the fact that it was necessary to overlap three centers. The difficulty lies not only in the appropriate overlap of the three centers but also in identifying which atom belongs to each center after the overlap. The results are presented in . The expected hierarchy, in which (Ω2)OPM > (Ω4)OPM > (Ω6)OPM, was observed for the three polyhedra.

The total radiative rate was obtained as the weighted average of the individual contributions of each polyhedron (eq ).

From the individual contribution of each polyhedron to the JO intensity parameters and A rad, we calculated the photophysical properties associated with each polyhedron using LUMPAC and the adequate kinetics equations. There is a good agreement between the percent contributions of each polyhedron to the A rad with the lifetime values; the polyhedron with the lowest excited-state lifetime contributes the least to the radiative rate. The total A rad of 314.27 s–1, obtained as the weighted average of each site, is on the same order of magnitude as the experimentally determined value of 354 s–1 (). This method also enables the determination of the theoretical triplet state energy; at 22 131 ± 1650 cm–1, it is close to the experimental value of 23 430 ± 600 cm–1 mentioned above.

elements.content: The donor–acceptor (R L) distances estimated for each unique polyhedron using LUMPAC are summarized in . Values of 5.91 and 5.92 Å were obtained for the octahedrally coordinated EuIII ions, Eu1, and Eu2, whereas a value of 9.30 Å was obtained for the seven-coordinate EuIII ion, Eu3. The physical meaning of the values of R L for the three distinct polyhedra was supported by density functional theory (DFT) calculations on the asymmetric unit of the crystal. The analysis of the frontier Kohn–Sham orbitals revealed that atoms that contribute to the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) orbitals come from different parts of the structure. As can be seen in , the HOMO has contributions from the four carboxylato groups coordinated to Eu3 and the LUMO is mainly the antibonding π-orbital of one of the 3,5-dcba bridges between Eu1 and Eu2. Because the LUMO is populated in the triplet state, this corroborates the calculated values of R L, in which the two matching values correspond to Eu1 and Eu2 and the longest to Eu3. Indeed, the distances from the centroid of the six-membered ring to Eu1, Eu2, and Eu3 are 6.0, 5.8, and 8.9 Å, respectively, in good agreement with the values obtained with LUMPAC ().

To estimate energy-transfer rates between donor and acceptor with the approach proposed by Malta in 2008, we did not consider the pathway through the singlet state of the ligand because of its small contribution. Instead, only the energy-transfer rates for the pathways T → 5D1 and T → 5D0 were calculated (). We observed that the rates of energy-transfer rates are at least 7 orders of magnitude faster than the energy back-transfer rates, which is consistent with the energy gap in excess of 3000 cm–1 between triplet and 5D1,0 levels, which effectively prevents energy back-transfer. In addition, and as we have previously shown, for equal values of triplet state energy, the rates of energy transfer decrease with increasing values of R L.

In addition, and as we have previously shown, for equal values of triplet state energy, the rates of energy transfer decrease with increasing values of R L.

elements.content: The theoretical intrinsic quantum yields (ΦEu Eu) associated with each unique center are summarized in . The larger values of ∼27 and ∼30% are attributed to the eight-coordinate Eu1 and Eu2, which do not have bound water molecules, and the smaller value of ∼13% is associated with Eu3, which contains a coordinated water molecule. By adding the individual contributions of each EuIII, we could assume that a total intrinsic efficiency of 69.08% would be possible for this coordination polymer, slightly higher than the value of 51% determined experimentally. Because in this OPM methodology there is no way to evaluate the energy transfer between each polyhedron, which is possible due to the proximity of the metal centers (vide supra), it allows only to evaluate the individual contributions of each polyhedron, it is unsurprising that the theoretically determined total intrinsic efficiency is higher than the experimental one.

A nrad is correlated with the deactivation of the 5D0 excited state by vibronic coupling, back energy transfer, or cross-relaxation processes. The higher value of the A nrad for the polyhedron 3, compared with polyhedra 1 and 2, is consistent with the deactivation of the 5D0 excited level by O–H vibronic coupling of the coordinated water molecules to Eu3. elements.content: A new EuIII coordination polymer with three unique coordination sites in the asymmetric unit was synthesized and its structure determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The contribution of each unique EuIII ion to the photophysical parameters of the complex was estimated theoretically. The OPM provided the best match between calculated and experimentally obtained photophysical data compared with the centroid method and the IPM. The frontier orbitals, calculated by DFT, were used to confirm the donor–acceptor distances (R L) calculated using semi-empirical methods and justify the slow rate of energy-transfer ligand → Eu3. The agreement between theoretically calculated and experimentally obtained A rad and ΦEu Eu shows that the OPM was successfully used to predict the individual contribution of each unique EuIII site in the total photophysical properties of the coordination polymer. The application of the OPM to several polyhedra as described herein, as an accessible method that does not require long calculation times, will enable researchers to determine easily the individual contribution of each unique site to the global photophysical properties of polymeric systems. This will lead to a better understanding and design of polymeric systems or metal–organic frameworks for luminescence applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new EuIII coordination polymer with three unique coordination sites in the asymmetric unit was synthesized and its structure determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The contribution of each unique EuIII ion to the photophysical parameters of the complex was estimated theoretically. The OPM provided the best match between calculated and experimentally obtained photophysical data compared with the centroid method and the IPM. The frontier orbitals, calculated by DFT, were used to confirm the donor-acceptor distances (R L) calculated using semi-empirical methods and justify the slow rate of energy-transfer ligand → Eu3. The agreement between theoretically calculated and experimentally obtained A rad and ΦEu Eu shows that the OPM was successfully used to predict the individual contribution of each unique EuIII site in the total photophysical properties of the coordination polymer. The application of the OPM to several polyhedra as described herein, as an accessible method that does not require long calculation times, will enable researchers to determine easily the individual contribution of each unique site to the global photophysical properties of polymeric systems. This will lead to a better understanding and design of polymeric systems or metal-organic frameworks for luminescence applications.

Experimental Section

All commercially obtained reagents were of analytical grade and were used as received. Unless otherwise noted, all reactions were performed in air. Solvents were purified by standard methods. Carbon and hydrogen elemental analysis was obtained on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer.

elements.content: EuCl3 was obtained by the addition of hydrochloric acid to an aqueous suspension of europium oxide. After complete dissolution, the pH of the solution was adjusted to ∼4 with dilute aqueous ammonium hydroxide (0.1 M). The concentration of EuIII was determined by complexometric titration with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (0.01 M) using xylenol orange as the indicator.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Solutions of EuCl3 

EuCl3 was obtained by the addition of hydrochloric acid to an aqueous suspension of europium oxide. After complete dissolution, the pH of the solution was adjusted to ~4 with dilute aqueous ammonium hydroxide (0.1 M). The concentration of EuIII was determined by complexometric titration with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (0.01 M) using xylenol orange as the indicator.

elements.content: Sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous suspension of 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid (70 mg, 0.37 mmol) in a 1:1 (3,5-dcba/OH–) stoichiometry and stirred for 30 min at 80 °C. The aqueous solution of the deprotonated ligand was added to an aqueous EuCl3 solution (15 mL, 8.2 mM) in a 1:3 (Eu/3,5-dcba) stoichiometry. A white precipitate formed, and the suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The white solid was isolated by filtration and washed with hot water and methanol. Yield: quantitative. Single crystals of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow diffusion of water into a dmf solution of the solid.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Isolation of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)(dmf)3]⋅2dmf 

Sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous suspension of 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid (70 mg, 0.37 mmol) in a 1:1 (3,5-dcba/OH-) stoichiometry and stirred for 30 min at 80 °C. The aqueous solution of the deprotonated ligand was added to an aqueous EuCl3 solution (15 mL, 8.2 mM) in a 1:3 (Eu/3,5-dcba) stoichiometry. A white precipitate formed, and the suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The white solid was isolated by filtration and washed with hot water and methanol. Yield: quantitative. Single crystals of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)(dmf)3]⋅2dmf suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow diffusion of water into a dmf solution of the solid.

Spectroscopic Characterization

Unless otherwise indicated, all data were collected at constant temperature of 298.0 ± 1.0 K. The photoluminescence data were obtained with the samples in the solid state in a Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter (HORIBA FL3-22-iHR320), with a double-grating (1200 g/mm, blazed at 330 nm) excitation monochromator and double-grating (1200 g/mm, blazed at 500 nm) emission monochromator. A 450 W ozone-free xenon lamp (Ushio) was used as the radiation source. The excitation spectra were obtained between 250 and 500 nm and were corrected in real time according to the lamp intensity and the optical system of the excitation monochromator using a silicon diode as the reference detector. The emission spectra were obtained between 550 and 750 nm using the front face mode at 22.5°. All emission spectra were corrected according to the optical system of the emission monochromator and the photomultiplier response (Hamamatsu R928P). The emission decay curves were obtained with a pulsed 150 W xenon lamp using a TCSPC system. The ligand’s triplet energy level value was obtained at ∼77 K by deconvolution of the phosphorescence spectrum into its Franck–Condon progression and is reported as the 0–0 transition. The JO intensity parameters Ω2 and Ω4 were calculated using published equations implemented in the LUMPAC software package, λexc = 305 and the compound in the solid state. The radiative decay rate A rad, the total decay rate A tot, and the intrinsic emission efficiency of EuIII ΦEu Eu were determined using –, respectively. elements.content: Crystal data, data collection, and refinement details for [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf are summarized in Table S1. Eu–O bond lengths for this complex are shown in Table S2. A suitable crystal was mounted on a glass fiber and placed in the low-temperature nitrogen stream (100 K). Data were collected on a Bruker APEX II DUO area detector diffractometer equipped with a low-temperature device (Oxford Cryosystems 700 series), using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were measured using a strategy combining ω and φ scans of 0.3° per frame and an acquisition time of 10 s per frame. Multiscan absorption correction was applied. Cell parameters were retrieved using the SMART software and refined using SAINTPlus on all observed reflections. Data reduction and correction for L p and decay were performed using the SAINTPlus software. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were added geometrically, and their parameters constrained to the parent site. Although the complex formula is correct, the hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecule have been omitted because they could not be located on the difference map or added geometrically. The X-ray crystallographic information file can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K.; Fax +44 1223 336033; E-mail data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk). CCDC 1843437 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf in this paper.

elements.content: A crystallographic fragment containing an asymmetric unit of the crystal was used to calculate the excited state energies of the ligands. In this calculation, the INDO/S-CIS method implemented in ORCA v.4.0.1 was used and the EuIII ions were replaced by a +3e point charge. DFT calculations were performed with ORCA v.4.0.1. In all cases, the hybrid PBE0 functional was used with a 10–8 E h convergence criterion for the energy change. Because of the size of the computational problem, the def2-SVP basis set was used for all light atoms along with corresponding effective core potential (ECP) potentials (except hydrogen). In the case of europium, the Stuttgart–Dresden ECP with 52 core electrons, including f-electrons, was used along with the corresponding basis set. The RIJCOSX approximation was used in all calculations with the default auxiliary built-in basis sets. The geometry of the ground state was calculated from the single-crystal structure after optimization of hydrogen atom positions at the same level of theory. The asymmetric units were calculated as gas-phase molecules with 3-charge.
elements.clean_text:
Ground-State Geometries and Theoretical Calculations

A crystallographic fragment containing an asymmetric unit of the crystal was used to calculate the excited state energies of the ligands. In this calculation, the INDO/S-CIS method implemented in ORCA v.4.0.1 was used and the EuIII ions were replaced by a +3e point charge. DFT calculations were performed with ORCA v.4.0.1. In all cases, the hybrid PBE0 functional was used with a 10-8 E h convergence criterion for the energy change. Because of the size of the computational problem, the def2-SVP basis set was used for all light atoms along with corresponding effective core potential (ECP) potentials (except hydrogen). In the case of europium, the Stuttgart-Dresden ECP with 52 core electrons, including f-electrons, was used along with the corresponding basis set. The RIJCOSX approximation was used in all calculations with the default auxiliary built-in basis sets. The geometry of the ground state was calculated from the single-crystal structure after optimization of hydrogen atom positions at the same level of theory. The asymmetric units were calculated as gas-phase molecules with 3-charge.

cln_elements.content: Sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous suspension of 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid (70 mg, 0.37 mmol) in a 1:1 (3,5-dcba/OH–) stoichiometry and stirred for 30 min at 80 °C. The aqueous solution of the deprotonated ligand was added to an aqueous EuCl3 solution (15 mL, 8.2 mM) in a 1:3 (Eu/3,5-dcba) stoichiometry. A white precipitate formed, and the suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The white solid was isolated by filtration and washed with hot water and methanol. Yield: quantitative. Single crystals of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow diffusion of water into a dmf solution of the solid.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Isolation of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)(dmf)3]⋅2dmf 

Sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous suspension of 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid (70 mg, 0.37 mmol) in a 1:1 (3,5-dcba/OH-) stoichiometry and stirred for 30 min at 80 °C. The aqueous solution of the deprotonated ligand was added to an aqueous EuCl3 solution (15 mL, 8.2 mM) in a 1:3 (Eu/3,5-dcba) stoichiometry. A white precipitate formed, and the suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. The white solid was isolated by filtration and washed with hot water and methanol. Yield: quantitative. Single crystals of [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)(dmf)3]⋅2dmf suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow diffusion of water into a dmf solution of the solid.

cln_elements.content: The complex [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)­(dmf)3]·2dmf was obtained by reacting 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid in NaOH with europium chloride, and X-ray quality single crystals were isolated from diffusion of water into a DMF solution. This complex crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, as a coordination polymer with unit cell dimensions a = 12.4899(15), b = 16.326(2), and c = 25.059(3) Å, α = 84.271(3), β = 84.832(3), and γ = 68.585(3)° and V = 4725.2(10) Å3. Although one or two different sites for LnIII ions are often encountered for complexes containing benzoic acid and its derivatives, here there are three unique EuIII coordination sites, as shown in , with the three unique EuIII ions bridged by κ2-O-3,5-dichlorobenzoato anions.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The complex [Eu3(3,5-dcba)9(H2O)(dmf)3]⋅2dmf was obtained by reacting 3,5-dichlorobenzoic acid in NaOH with europium chloride, and X-ray quality single crystals were isolated from diffusion of water into a DMF solution. This complex crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, as a coordination polymer with unit cell dimensions a = 12.4899(15), b = 16.326(2), and c = 25.059(3) Å, α = 84.271(3), β = 84.832(3), and γ = 68.585(3)° and V = 4725.2(10) Å3. Although one or two different sites for LnIII ions are often encountered for complexes containing benzoic acid and its derivatives, here there are three unique EuIII coordination sites, as shown in , with the three unique EuIII ions bridged by κ2-O-3,5-dichlorobenzoato anions.
